name: q14_2
probTex: Let $f$ be an entire function such that $|f(z)|< M|z|^\alpha$ for all $z\in\mathbb{C}$, where $M,R,\alpha$ are constants and $0<\alpha<1$. Prove $f$ is constant.
solnTex:
Let $z_0\in\mathbb{C}$. Take the power series of $f$ centered at $0$,
\[f(z)=\sum_{n=0}^\infty rac{f^{(n)}(0)}{n!}z^n.\]
Let $R>0$ and rewrite the coefficients using Cauchy's integral formula,
\[f^{(n)}(0)= rac{n!}{2\pi i}\int_{|w|=R} rac{f(w)}{w^{n+1}}dw.\]
Using the assumption that $|f(w)|< M|w|^\alpha$ gives
\[|f^{(n)}(0)|\leq rac{n!}{2\pi}\int_{|w|=R} rac{MR^\alpha}{R^{n+1}}|dw|= rac{n!M}{R^{n+1-\alpha}}.\]
Now $n\geq0$ and $\alpha<1$ so $n+1-\alpha>0$. Thus $ rac{n!M}{R^{n+1-\alpha}}	o0$ as $R	o\infty$. We are using the fact that $f$ is entire when we let $R	o\infty$. Thus $f^{(n)}(0)=0$ for all $n\geq0$, meaning all coefficients in the power series are $0$, so $f$ is constantly 0.
Note that we showed $f=0$, which is stronger than $f$ is constant. That is because of the way this question is worded, in fact $|f(0)|\leq M|0|^\alpha=0$ so $f$ being constant implies that $f$ is $0$ under this bound.
